intro: Ricinus communis var. americanus, commonly known as the American castor oil plant, is a flowering plant native to the Americas. It is characterized by its large, palmate leaves and distinctive spiny capsules that contain toxic seeds. The plant is part of the Euphorbiaceae family and is known for its ability to thrive in a variety of soil types. It produces a sticky, milky sap that can cause skin irritation. The species is cultivated for its seeds, which are used to produce castor oil.
